item.title: my take a sad plot and make it better- Uno
item.description: library(tidyverse) library(viridis) # colors! library(beyonce) # colors!! library(extrafont) # fonts! ratings <- read_csv("http://bit.ly/cs631-ratings", na = c("", "NA", "N/A"), col_types = cols( viewers_7day = col_number(), series = col_factor(levels = NULL) )) # some small wrangling ratings_bonanza1 <- ratings %>% mutate(ep_id = row_number(), series = as.factor(series)) %>% select(ep_id, viewers_7day, series) # my colors from beyonce mybey <- beyonce_palette(66)[c(11,10,7,6,5,4,3,1)] # make the plot ggplot(ratings_bonanza1, aes(x = ep_id, y = viewers_7day, fill = series)) + geom_col(alpha = .

item.title: take a sad plot and make it better- take 2
item.description: Packages library(tidyverse) library(viridis) # colors! library(beyonce) # colors!! library(extrafont) # fonts! The data Here I read in a local data file using this advice: https://blogdown-demo.rbind.io/2018/02/27/r-file-paths/#place-file-in-your-staticdata-folder ratings <- read_csv(here::here("static", "data", "episodes.csv"), na = c("", "NA", "N/A"), col_types = cols( viewers_7day = col_number(), series = col_factor(levels = NULL) )) Recipe 2: Lollipop Plot ratings_bonanza2 <- ratings %>% group_by(series) %>% mutate(series_avg = mean(viewers_7day, na.rm = TRUE), diff_avg = viewers_7day - series_avg)%>% filter(max(episode) == 10) %>% mutate(episode = as.

item.title: About
item.description: From a Wikipedia article on me: I am an English writer. I became the world’s first computer programmer. I wrote the program for Charles Babbage’s mechanical computer, “The Analytical Engine”, in 1844. I wrote the first algorithm to be processed by a machine. Between 1842 and 1843, I translated an article by Italian mathematician Luigi Menabrea on the engine. I added my own notes to it. These notes contain what is considered the first computer program, which was an algorithm encoded for processing by a machine.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: knitr::include_url("../../slides/slides.html") R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.
